content.text: How far, in km, does the car travel in \(1\sfrac{1}{2}\) hour at the speed shown in Fig. 1.1?
distance = .........km
On the axes shown in Fig. 1.2, draw a line representing the motion of the car \(1 / 2\) hour mentioned in (a). Do not go beyond \(1 / 2\) hour
At the end of the \(1 / 2\) hour, the car reaches a region where the road begins to rise up into some mountains. The car climbs the mountains for a further \(1 / 2\) hour
During the climb, its speed steadily decreases to \(30\mathrm{km / hour.}\) The driver then stops the car so that he can admire the view
On Fig. 1.2, draw a line representing the climb and the stopping of the car. [4]
[Total: 10]
A car is travelling along a level road at a steady speed. Fig. 1.1 shows the speedometer the car. A speedometer registers how fast the car is going
the volume of the added water,
volume = .........cm³
the mass of the added water,
the density of water, stating clearly the equation you are using
density = .........

A student carries out an experiment to find the density of water, using a method slightly different from normal. In his method, he starts with a measuring cylinder containing some water, and then adds more water to that already in the measuring cylinder
His experiment is illustrated in Fig. 2.1
The readings he obtains are as follows:
Calculate
Mark these forces on Fig. 3.1, using an arrow labelled 70 000N and an arrow labelled 25 000N. [2]
State the direction of this force
Calculate the size of this force
Suggest what might be causing this force
The train is travelling at constant speed, so there must be another horizontal force acting on it
What happens to the train?
Why does this happen?
[Total: 7]
Once the train has passed the station, the driver increases the engine's forward thrust
All other forces stay the same
A train is passing through a station at constant speed, as shown in Fig. 3.1. The horizontal
The engine produces a forward thrust of 70000N. There is a 25 000N force opposing the motion, due to friction in the wheels
Explain, in terms of molecules, how a gas causes a pressure on the walls of its container
At constant temperature, the pressure of a gas increases as its volume
At constant volume, the pressure of a gas increases as its temperature

The principle of conservation of energy states that energy can neither be created nor destroyed

The potential difference across a wire may be measured by connecting
Complete the following sentences
A length of resistance wire is connected in a simple series circuit
The current in it is 0.8A. The potential difference across it is 9.6 V
Calculate the resistance of the wire
resistance = .........
the resistance in the circuit,
the current in the new wire when there is a potential difference of 9.6V across it, as before
